Stanbic IBTC Capital recently celebrated the listing of the ‚Ç¶250 billion Series IV Sovereign Sukuk Issuance with the Debt Management Office, FMDQ Securities Exchange Limited, the Nigerian Exchange Limited, and other Joint Issuing Houses on the transaction.
The Debt Management Office commenced the issuance of the Sovereign Sukuk in September 2017 as a strategic initiative to support the development of road infrastructure across Nigeria, promote financial inclusion and deepen the domestic securities market and Stanbic IBTC Capital is delighted to have acted as an Issuing House/Bookrunner to the fourth Series which occurred in 2021.
Supporting infrastructure development is a key focus area for Stanbic IBTC and we thank the Debt Management Office for trusting us and the other professional parties to guide the process to a successful completion.

Our Independently Managed Portfolios (IMP) are discretionary management agreements whereby clients delegate the day to day investment decisions and implementation of their chosen investment strategy to Stanbic IBTC Asset Management Limited while retaining the full beneficial ownership of their investments. #WealthWednesday

Our Portfolio Managers will initially meet with you to discuss your investment objectives. Then, in consultation with you and your advisers (where applicable), we will agree on a core investment strategy. The Portfolio Manager will then build a portfolio tailored to meet your investment objectives and requirements, and actively manage it going forward. 
It is important to note that the minimum required amount for portfolio management is 100million.

To know more, call 01 280 1266 or email assetmanagement@stanbicibtc.com #NeverStopInvesting #WealthWednesday

Here are ways to access/monitor your pension account at your fingertips with our shortcode service. 
#WealthWednesday

In addition, did you know that you can generate your statement online?
Simply follow the steps below:
Step 1: Visit www.stanbicibtcpension.com and look to the right hand of the screen (middle section). Click on the drop-down button and select ‚ÄúRSA Login‚Äù.
Step 2: Another window will appear advising you to login with your RSA PIN and Passcode or Registered Mobile Number and Passcode or Registered Email Address and Passcode which will take you to your account summary page (If you do not have your login details, kindly click on the ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know your passcode‚Äô‚Äô link; where you will be required to enter your complete 12 digit PIN number (starting with ‚ÄúPEN‚Äù without space). Once you have done this, your login details will be sent to your registered e-mail address and mobile number.
Step 3: Click on the ‚ÄúSTATEMENT‚Äù link on the Account Summary page.
Step 4: Enter the dates for which you want the statement to be generated and click ‚ÄúDownload Statement‚Äù. Your statement would download in a new tab. Bonus Tip: Please ensure to enable pop-up windows on your browser settings.

This week, we will be discussing the importance of making Voluntary Contributions (VC) to your pension fund. Voluntary Contributions (VCs) are additional contributions that can be made alongside the mandatory contributions remitted by your employer to your Retirement Savings Account (RSA). Yes, we do understand that these are difficult times. But, guess what ‚Äì a Naira saved is a Naira earned. So, if you want to #HappenToLife without worries, this is for you! 
#WealthWednesday

To make additional contributions into your RSA account, all you need to do is speak with your employer to make the necessary deductions from your monthly salary. Yes, it‚Äôs that simple and seamless! You should also note that Voluntary Contributions could be any amount of your choice, it could be as little as N1,000, as long it is from your legitimate income and not more than 1/3 of your monthly salary, in line with the Labour Act, 1990.
You are eligible to withdraw only 50% of your VC as long as the contributions have been retained in the account for at least 2 years. Subsequent withdrawals will be made after 2 years from the last withdrawal date. That is, if your last withdrawal date was January 2017, your next withdrawal date would be anytime from February 2019.
For more information, email pensionsolution@stanbicibtc.com 
Have a great and productive week! üòä 
#WealthWednesday
In addition to long-term benefits at retirement, here are some other benefits of making additional contributions to your RSA account. #WealthWednesday

The COVID-19 pandemic, followed by the lockdown has surely left many of us introspecting on how blessed our lives are, and how much of it we may have taken for granted. It is obvious now more than ever that tomorrow is not promised, so the best attitude to have, is to live every day like it‚Äôs your last (even as you plan for the future).
Speaking of the future, let us talk about Wills. A Will is a legal document that sets out who you want to receive your assets when you pass on. You can choose to write a simple Will or a comprehensive Will. 
#WealthWednesday

It is very important that you put a Legacee in place as you write down your wishes in a Will. This ensures a seamless transfer of your assets to your loved ones and family disputes can be avoided. You also have peace of mind knowing that if anything happens to you, your beneficiaries are catered for with the assets you have stated in your Will which in many instances is only known to you and may be lost if you had not written it down in your Will. 
#WealthWednesday

Imagine the consequences of not putting a #Legacee in place and leaving things to chance - they could unfold in ways you do not want. So while you are staying safe, be sure to reach out to us via Legacee@stanbicibtc.com to get you started on putting a Legacee in place and avoid stories that touch. 
#WealthWednesday

Be smart, always confirm from the bank before giving out any sensitive information via texts, phone calls or emails. Stay #moneysafe

Today, on our health-focused #WealthWednesday, we will be discussing the Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). What is PCOS? #PCOSAwarenessMonth

Early diagnosis and treatment of PCOS along with weight loss may reduce the risk of long-term complications such as type 2 diabetes and heart disease. #PCOSAwarenessMonth 
#WealthWednesday

PCOS develops during puberty around the time of the first menstrual period though the exact cause is unknown. #PCOSAwarenessMonth 
#WealthWednesday

Treatment of PCOS should focus on managing individual concerns, please do see a Medical Doctor if you have experienced any of these symptoms #PCOSAwarenessMonth

Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease that usually affects the lungs. Compared with other diseases caused by a single infectious agent, TB is the second biggest killer globally and it remains a serious health challenge in developing countries including Nigeria. 
#WealthWednesday

TB is spread through the air from one person to another. The TB germs are passed through the air when a person who is infected with the disease coughs, laughs, sings, or sneezes. Though highly contagious, but it is not easy to catch.
#WealthWednesday

The chances of spreading TB to someone you live or work with are much higher than to a stranger so, here are some ways to stop the spread of tuberculosis. 
#WealthWednesday

Reasons for estate planning are:
1. Inevitability of death: With healthcare services not as they should be, death rate among young Nigerians is on the rise. It would be unwise to die without a will.
2. Secure future for children: Many have died without a plan thereby forcing their children to leave school or be left to a relative who may feel pressured by the responsibility. Such children could turn to crime for survival.
3. Bitter litigation: When someone dies intestate, family members often lay claims on the person‚Äôs estate which may lead to legal disputes. Such disputes may lead to deaths and break up of families. It is therefore imperative to spare members of the family the pain of litigation and enmity by having a Will.
4. Lengthy probate: Probate is the legal certification of the validity of a Will. It is a process through which a Will must pass to ensure its validity. A probate can be difficult, but without a will, it could be demanding of time, effort, and money of loved ones. A Will ‚Äúensures that the assets are distributed according to express wishes.‚Äù
The requirements for a legacee are simple. Once a person attains adulthood, and plans on having a family, the plan allows him secure the future of his loved ones. To learn more, call 01-2706800.

Nkechi came home from a visit to her friend Bidemi, who had just lost her husband. Her in-laws had come to ‚Äúdiscuss‚Äù what to do with ‚Äútheir late brother‚Äôs property‚Äù. But it was clear that they had taken a decision before coming and were only there to pass on instructions. They instructed her to move out of the mansion in Ikeja where she lived into a smaller house  owned by the late husband. 
Nkechi shared this with her husband, and advised him to write his Will, as this would ensure a protected legacee for herself and their children. Like many, they had never thought about estate planning before and reasoned that such exercise is performed at old age. While she insisted, her husband got angry and accused her of wishing him premature death. 
This is a typical reaction by Nigerians when there‚Äôs a mention of legacee. It is likened to slapping one‚Äôs parents. Unfortunately, death is inevitable and the earlier one confronts his mortality, the better the quality of life for him and his family. Leaving a legacee requires a cautious attempt at estate planning and deploying such financial tools like a Trust. However, there are those who have no qualms about death but who are still passive regarding estate planning. To know more about Legacee, call 01-2706800.

Hi guys, how well do you know our Pension Laws? Test your knowledge with this trivia:
Zaynab had  a balance of N4,850,000 in her pension account at the time she passed away. What do you think will happen to this balance?  Options below, please reply with your answer or quote. 
 
1.    It is paid to the next of kin stated in the records she has with her chosen PFA.
2.    Once the PFA becomes aware of her demise, it will be transferred to her bank account by word of mouth.
3.   Her PFA gets to keep the money, even when they are aware that the account holder has died.
4.    The funds are paid to the beneficiaries stated on her will or letter of administration.
#WealthWednesday

According to the pension reform act, when a pension account holder passes on, the funds in their account goes to the beneficiary recognized by law. This means that the funds can only be paid to the named beneficiary in a Will. 
In the absence of a Will, the funds can then be released to the person who obtains and is named in the letter of Administration. 
To ensure that your funds are paid to your intended beneficiary(ies) and save them the rigors of getting a letter of administration, we advise that you put a Will in place. See how here: https://lnkd.in/dzB36YU

So, what is a Private Trust? #WealthWednesday

Trust funds accumulated over a lifetime are not divided amongst your beneficiaries after one passes on but are retained as one fund to accumulate more wealth. Funds will have provision for payment to members of the family as the need arises while preserving some funds to continue growing.
#WealthWednesday

How to care for kids born without limbs. #TuesdayThoughts

Congenital amputation can be a devastating experience for both the parents and child. It comes with adjustments no one plans for and realities that can be hard to accept. Here are a few thoughts we have on being there for a child who may need you:

1. Emotional support: Everyone does better when they know they are loved, especially children. This is the first and most important thing a child needs. 
2. Psychological support: It may be too much to cope with even as a parent or guardian, but you must remember to teach them to believe in their abilities, regardless of what has happened 
3. Physical support: Ensure to get them the right prosthesis for their age and the medical care they need ‚Äì dedicated physiotherapy usually helps. It is also important that you show them how to do things themselves.

Have more #thoughts to share with us? Kindly share with us in the comments.
#Together4ALimb

Hi there Parents & Guardians, how was #SchoolFeesWeek?

Now that the kids are back in school after the long holidays, it's a good idea to take some precautionary measures to set them up for a safe and healthy year as they readjust to various school activities. You may not be able to keep an eye on your child at school, but you can encourage them to develop healthy habits from a young age. So, here are seven health tips to consider as the kids settle into school. #WealthWednesday

Now that the kids are back in school after the long holidays, it's a good idea to take some precautionary measures to set them up for a safe and healthy year as they readjust to various school activities. You may not be able to keep an eye on your child at school, but you can encourage them to develop healthy habits from a young age. So, here are seven health tips to consider as the kids settle into school #WealthWednesday

Get vaccinated:
Children should get all vaccinations required especially if going to school for the first time. Make sure they're protected against common childhood diseases and illnesses. Check with your Pediatrician and vaccination records for guidance to be sure that your child is up to date on vaccines.
#WealthWednesday

Set bedtime:
A healthy amount of sleep each night is needed to stay focused throughout the day. Consider making their bedtime a little earlier each night for a week or two before school starts. Sticking to a routine is important too, don‚Äôt let weekends become late-night free-for-alls.
#WealthWednesday

Teach good hygiene habits:
To help your kids avoid getting sick (prevent them from bringing germs home), it's important to show them how to protect themselves. Ensure that their lunchbox is kept clean and hygienic. Teach them to wash their hands after using the restroom and before going to lunch or eating a snack.
#WealthWednesday

Stock up on healthy foods:
Stock up on healthy foods like fruits, vegetables, whole-grain bread and lean protein like chicken. Avoid junk food. Good nutrition helps the child to focus and concentrate. Ensure kids eat a healthy breakfast (they're more alert and do better in school if they eat a good breakfast every day).
#WealthWednesday

Manage school stress:
Back-to-school season is stressful for kids and parents alike. 
Kids may have physical symptoms such as stomach aches and nausea from "making themselves sick over the worry and anxiety. Schoolwork and after-school activities are important, it's also essential to take time to relax, play and spend time as a family.
#WealthWednesday

Backpack Problems:
Overloaded backpacks could hurt your child's back. Some children may do well with a rolling backpack like the wheeled suitcase their parents take on business trips. Make sure the backpack has wide straps and a padded back reaching to waist region. Inappropriately used backpack can expose child to issues such as back pain.
#WealthWednesday

Be aware of allergens:
Children who suffer from allergies suffer as dust mites, mold, and other allergens may be present in the classroom. For some kids, it means a runny nose, sneezing, coughing, and watery eyes, which can also trigger asthma or lead indirectly to sinus infections.
#WealthWednesday

We know that School can put pressure on children and parents/guardians. But we know you‚Äôve got this! We wish you all a fantastic school term.
 #WealthWednesday

How often do you take up a travel insurance policy?  #WealthWednesday
A.    Every time
B.    Never
C.   Sometimes
D.   What is that?
Why is travel insurance necessary? Well, It is designed to provide financial protection for unexpected events during one‚Äôs trip. #WealthWednesday
Wondering if and why you need travel insurance? Here are a few benefits to consider; #WealthWednesday

Emergency return home following death of close relative - 
Where insured‚Äôs trip is interrupted by the death of a close relative (as defined by the policy) ,the insurer will cover travel costs whenever the insured is unable to personally cover such trips. 

Repatriation of mortal remains - 
In the event of the death of the insured, the insurance company will necessary arrangements for the return of the insured‚Äôs remains to the insured‚Äôs country of citizenship.

Loss of passport, driver‚Äôs license and national identity card while abroad - 
The insurer will take charge of the expenses of replacements. 

Delayed departure - 
In the event of a delay of more than 4 hours, the insurer shall re-imburse any additional expenses incurred for transport, hotel accommodation as well as meals, loss of baggage and personal possessions. #WealthWednesday
However, travel insurance is not eligible for the following categories; #WealthWednesday

How much time do you spend on your phone/electronic device everyday on the average? Technology is doing so much for us but it does have drawbacks. For instance, more young people are seeking medical advice for neck and backache due to the excessive use of mobile devices.
In fact, experts have verified that amongst young people aged between 16 and 34 years, there is a 60 per cent increase in those suffering from ‚Äútech-neck‚Äù. #WealthWednesday

This unnatural posture strains muscles in the neck and chest area and if left unaddressed can increase the risk of pinched nerves, bone spurs and degenerative disk disease. It can also lead to you having a Hunchback. 
The good news is that by being aware of it and taking a few corrective actions, we can minimize and correct the negative (and unattractive) impacts of tech neck. #WealthWednesday

How to test for Tech Neck:
The best way to know is to physically see what your spine, shoulder and neck are doing right now. 
Do you have Tech Neck?
If you find yourself looking down more at your smart phone than you did in the past, please review your current posture.Your device viewing position may feel comfortable and completely natural but it doesn‚Äôt mean your posture is great. #WealthWednesday

Why is travel insurance necessary? Well, It is designed to provide financial protection for unexpected events during one‚Äôs trip. Wondering if and why you need travel insurance? Here are a few benefits to consider;¬†

1. Emergency dental care
The insurer will provide the individual with dental assistance required abroad.¬†
2. Medical Care in the event of an illness or injury
The insurer will pay the cost of hospitalization, surgery, medical fees and pharmaceutical products,prescribed by the attending doctor.¬†
3. Repatriation of family member travelling with the insured
Should the insured be hospitalized due to sudden illness or accident for more than 10 days, the insurer will meet the cost of repatriating one immediate family memberaccompanying the insured at the time of the event to his usual place of residence.
4. Cover for accidents or sudden illness (not pre-existing)
The insurer will be responsible for transferring the individual to a properly equipped health centre and repatriating the insured to his/her usual country of residence. #WealthWednesday
However, travel insurance is not eligible for the following categories; #WealthWednesday

Why travel insurance?¬†
5. Emergency return home following death of close relative
Where insured‚Äôs trip is interrupted by the death of a close relative(as defined by the policy) ,the insurer will cover travel costswhenever the insured is unable to personally cover such trips.¬†
6. Repatriation of mortal remains
In the event of the death of the insured, the insurance company will necessary arrangements for the return of the insured‚Äôs remains to the insured‚Äôs country of citizenship. 
7.Loss of passport, driver‚Äôs license and national identity card while abroad
The insurer will take charge of the expenses of replacements. 
8. Delayed departure-in the event of a delay of more than 4 hours,the insurer shall re-imburse any additional expenses incurred for transport, hotel  accommodation as well as meals, loss of baggage and personal possessions. #WealthWednesday

On May 17, the world celebrated World Hypertension Day. Today, as we focus on health, we thought to spend it educating us a little so we can live better. Health is Wealth, right? So, what really is hypertension? Hypertension is a health condition in which blood pressure is persistently elevated putting undue stress on the heart, blood vessels and other organs. In 9 of 10 cases, the cause of hypertension cannot be identified. However, certain factors such as ‚Äì Hereditary, Environmental, Lifestyle (weight, diet, alcohol, smoking, physical inactivity and medication) are considered contributory. It is often referred to as the ‚Äòsilent killer‚Äô because it can exist with no obvious symptoms. The only way to detect it is by monitoring your blood pressure. Blood pressure is not a fixed number. It varies with physical activity, excitement, time of day or night, and with emotional factors. This is why it is important to have your blood pressure taken under proper conditions and regularly. The higher the blood pressure, the greater the cardiovascular risk. The longer the duration of hypertension, the greater the cardiovascular risk. #WealthWednesday

On May 17, the world celebrated World Hypertension Day. Today, as we focus on health, we thought to spend it educating us a little so we can live better. Health is Wealth, right? So, what really is hypertension? Hypertension is a health condition in which blood pressure is persistently elevated putting undue stress on the heart, blood vessels and other organs. #WealthWednesday

In 9 of 10 cases, the cause of hypertension cannot be identified. However, certain factors such as ‚Äì Hereditary, Environmental, Lifestyle (weight, diet, alcohol, smoking, physical inactivity and medication) are considered contributory. It is often referred to as the ‚Äòsilent killer‚Äô because it can exist with no obvious symptoms. The only way to detect it is by monitoring your blood pressure. Blood pressure is not a fixed number. It varies with physical activity, excitement, time of day or night, and with emotional factors. This is why it is important to have your blood pressure taken under proper conditions and regularly. #WealthWednesday
The higher the blood pressure, the greater the cardiovascular risk. The longer the duration of hypertension, the greater the cardiovascular risk. #WealthWednesday

Is hypertension treatable? It can be successfully managed but is not curable so what can you do to better manage your health?¬†
-	Be aware of your family‚Äôs medical history so you know if you are at risk. Always allow your BP to be taken whenever you are in the hospital and know and track your numbers.
-	If you are at risk, please see a doctor and get treatment quickly. It‚Äôs always advisable to begin with healthy lifestyle changes.  #WealthWednesday

No one's blood pressure is constant. Exercise or even a sudden burst of anger can raise our blood pressure readings, although not to dangerous levels or for long periods of time. Secondly, it is a killer. People who have hypertension that is not treated are much more likely to die from or be disabled by complications such as strokes, heart attacks, heart failure, heart rhythm irregularities, and kidney failure than people who have normal blood pressure. #WealthWednesday

If you have been monitoring your pension account like we advised, you might have noticed that your balance has been earning some returns.

But have you ever wondered how the funds in your pension account are being managed? We think it‚Äôs important to know so, we will be providing just a little insight into that. #WealthWednesday

Well Pencomng has provided an investment guideline and this basically guides PFAs as to what asset classes and the exposure each PFA can have to these different Asset Classes.

At present, contributions from all RSA holders who are not retired (irrespective of their ages and risk criteria) are invested together as one pool called the RSA Active Fund. #WealthWednesday

The first pool of funds (Fund 1) will have a higher exposure to the equities market (and other assets with varying returns) than all the other funds and is available to RSA holders who are less than 50 years from commencement of the multi fund structure.

Fund 2 will be the default fund for all RSA holders who are less than 50 years as at 1 July 2018. This fund has a medium exposure to the equities market.

Fund 3 will be the default fund for all RSA holders who are above 50 years as at 1 July 2018 but are yet to retire. This is a conservative fund with a low exposure to the equities market.

However, the RSA Retirees fund which currently exists and caters to all retirees currently receiving pension will remain and will be called Fund 4. #WealthWednesday

However, from 1 July 2018, the RSA Active Fund will be split into three funds with different investment criteria. This new structure gives you, the contributor, a choice to opt for more risk/returns by switching between funds where eligible. #WealthWednesday

Today is our health & wellness edition of #WealthWednesday, so we thought to shed more light on Autism & Autism Spectrum disorder as April is Autism Awareness month. Autism and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) are both general terms for a group of complex disorders of brain development, characterized, in varying degrees, by difficulties in social interaction, verbal and nonverbal communication and repetitive behaviours.
Autism is a complex neurobehavioral condition that includes impairments in social interaction, developmental language and communication skills combined with rigid, repetitive behaviours.¬†
Autism spectrum disorder can often be difficult to diagnose. At present, there's no official test for diagnosing autism. #WealthWednesday

Most children affected by the disorder do not have intellectual disabilities, some study finds, and even among the severely low-functioning, about 10% may improve dramatically over time, with some growing out of their diagnosis by their teens. #WealthWednesday

So here are some strategies for promoting language development in nonverbal children and adolescents with autism:
1. Encourage play and social interaction - Children learn through play, and that includes learning language. Interactive play provides enjoyable opportunities for you and your child to communicate. Try a variety of games to find those your child enjoys.
2. Imitate your child - Mimicking your child‚Äôs sounds and play behaviours will encourage more vocalizing and interaction. It also encourages your child to copy you and take turns.
3. Focus on nonverbal communication - Gestures and eye contact can build a foundation for language. Encourage your child by modelling and responding these behaviours.
 #WealthWednesday

More strategies for promoting language development in non-verbal children and adolescents with autism:
4. Leave ‚Äúspace‚Äù for your child to talk - It‚Äôs natural to feel the urge to fill in language when a child doesn‚Äôt immediately respond. But it‚Äôs so important to give your child lots of opportunities to communicate, even if he isn‚Äôt talking.	
5. Simplify your language - Doing so helps your child follow what you‚Äôre saying. It also makes it easier for her to imitate your speech.	
6. Follow your child's interests - Rather than interrupting your child‚Äôs focus, follow along with words. Using the one-up rule, narrate what your child is doing.
7. Consider assistive devices and visual supports - Assistive technologies and visual supports can do more than take the place of speech. They can foster its development. #WealthWednesday

Are you making yourself wealthy or just earning an income?

Have you ever wondered how some sports stars become broke despite making millions during their careers? It‚Äôs because wealth is not measured by the amount of money that comes into one‚Äôs pocket, but by the amount that stays there.

Building your wealth requires some self-discipline and deliberate actions.You need to save and invest to create wealth. Those are the actions required. The main idea behind investing is to put the money you‚Äôve saved into things you think will go up or at least maintain value over time. What kind of things? Is it just us or do you guys think people tend to know when we have excess money so they can borrow? Give or lend as you please, but if you realise that you usually have spare cash after all your planned expenses then this might be a sign that you should be saving more. Or if you find yourself spending on certain things too often, could be those cinema tickets, your dressy accessories or the usual turn up on Fridays, you could also consider these as a sign that you could be saving more. Now, let‚Äôs create a scenario:¬†
How about you forego some of those extra expenses and commit those funds as an additional contribution towards your pension? We call these voluntary contributions.¬†Imagine the amount you would have accrued at retirement if you make this slight adjustment for a couple of years. #WealthWednesday

Now it gets interesting, remember pension funds are deducted at source & these deductions are done before taxes? Your voluntary contributions are also treated as such, thus helping you to legitimately save on taxes as you save more towards retirement. Your voluntary contributions are also invested like the funds in your retirement savings account, which means your total contributions continue to grow thus accomplishing something significantly bigger than the expenditure you had to forego: this is the amazing power of voluntary contributions. All you need to do is make a deliberate decision to start today.¬†

Last week we celebrated the International Women‚Äôs Day globally and Sunday was Mother‚Äôs Day for many people across the globe. Today, our #WealthWednesday will be focusing on Women‚Äôs Health. Women and men share many similar health problems, but women also have their own health issues, which deserve special consideration and it is also helpful that men understand and are supportive of the health concerns of the women. A few women specific health issues are- breast cancer, cervical cancer, and bone density screenings. Issues unique to women include pregnancy, menopause, and conditions of the female organs. #WealthWednesday

Some diseases occur at a higher frequency in women.  Gallstones are three to four times more common in women than in men as are migraine headaches at a ratio of three females to one male. Also, the effects of sexually transmitted diseases can be more serious in women. #WealthWednesday
The biggest threats to women's health are often preventable. Here's what you need to know to live a longer, healthier life.
1.	Follow a Heart-Healthy Diet
2.	Exercise Every Day
3.	Visit Your Doctor
4.	Cut Down Your stress 
5.	Create Healthy Habits
6.	Take time every day to invest in your health.

A Mutual fund is an investment scheme that pools investors‚Äô funds together to be expertly managed by a Fund Manager with the purpose of achieving returns better than they would have, had they invested individually, so how does a mutual fund work? It involves collection of money from various retail investors and then buying wholesale investments on their behalf and sharing the returns amongst the participants in line with their investment amounts. Remember how Mumsy used to collabo with a group of friends to buy foodstuffs from the market in bulk, and then they‚Äôd split amongst themselves to save cost and get better quality foodstuff? This works similarly. #WealthWednesday

Just like a banker will offer a better rate to a depositor with N5,000,000 than to one with N100,000. Mutual funds remind us that we can come together so that our N100,000 earns like returns with the N5,000,000. Everyone brings what they have, N5,000, N10,000, N1m and the money together forms a pool of cash that can be invested. These funds are then managed by a Fund Manager like Stanbic IBTC Asset management who makes all the investment decisions. One of the benefits you get is having access to returns from the total amount in the fund alongside all the other investors. So all you do is put your money in, and watch it grow as you earn returns on your investment. Mutual funds are also open-ended, that means you do not have to wait till a specific time to get your money out. Also, your investment is liquid (easily converted to cash) at any time you need it. Sounds good right? #WealthWednesday

#WealthWednesday

And with access to an online platform similar to your internet banking, you can keep an eye on your funds, make additional investments, partial or full withdrawals and even switch between different fund types at any time. Do you know your employer should remit your pension payments no later than seven (7) days after your salary is paid? #WealthWednesday
Beyond the fact that making pension contributions is compulsory in Nigeria, these contributions serve as a great place to start planning towards that retirement you deserve. The best advice is to become more deliberate about contributing towards your pension. So here are a few tips on how to make this happen. 
- Monitor your account: There are several easy options to help you monitor the inflows into your pension account. Monitoring helps you determine if the contributions into your account are consistent and adequate to fund the retirement you dream of. #WealthWednesday

'- Have a plan and write it down so you can work towards your goal. Here‚Äôs the link to our pension calculator to help you forecast and plan right: http://bit.ly/2sIQGIC¬†
- Using your plan, will your current monthly payment be sufficient to fund your retirement? If not, you may need to augment the amount your employer remits by making additional voluntary contributions.¬†

Need to learn more about saving towards retirement? Please call us on 01-2716000 or email pensionsolution@stanbicibtc.com, our gurus are available to answer your questions. #WealthWednesday.

What is the most expensive gift you‚Äôve given or received from your valentine? #WealthWednesday

Valentine‚Äôs Day üíï  is in a week everyone. So this #WealthWednesday, we‚Äôll be talking about the second best part ‚Äì giving and receiving gifts üéÅ. Don‚Äôt get us wrong, the gifts are great. But the best part of it all is the thought that comes with the gift ‚Äì the intent to make someone feel special.

While all gifts are valuable, it‚Äôs always a good idea to take the most care of those really obviously expensive gifts üíé üöó üì±. One way is by being very careful with them. Another is keeping them safe. Allow us to recommend a third option ‚Äì insuring them. #WealthWednesday

Did you know that jewellery and other expensive items aren‚Äôt automatically covered under a homeowner‚Äôs policy? So, in the off-chance that you experience a loss of said items from your home, and the cause of the loss is not specifically mentioned in your policy, you may not be covered and compensated üò≤. That‚Äôs why we are here: to help protect your most valued possessions ‚Äì especially those received from the one who loves you. So, if you receive really expensive gifts this Valentine‚Äôs Day, let‚Äôs make them priceless by protecting not just the gift, but the memories with an insurance policy. Amongst other things, Christmas for us means the end of the year is here. It is a good time to revisit our goals for the year and what we have achieved. It is also a good time to plan for the New Year. As we know, the festive season is a joyous time, but it can be stressful and stretch your finances, which leaves us starting the New Year playing catch up. To avoid this, planning is essential. Short (2018), medium (2019) and long (retirement) term goals must be on the table. #WealthWednesday

Here are some financial tips to ensure you enjoy the season, while making better spending decisions and being prepared for 2018.The first step is to:
1. Assess where you are now. How well did you do with your 2017 goals? Are there areas to improve on? Are there areas where you did well and would like to build on? Set SMART - Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Realistic and Time bound goals.
2. Prioritize your debt. Make a list of your liabilities and expected outflows. You may want to pay some attention to reducing your liabilities 
3.. Start an emergency fund with the goal of having the equivalent of about 3- 6 months‚Äô salary saved for the rainy day. Just have something saved!!! #WealthWednesday
Self Development is in! Looking to advance your career next year? Read books, take online courses that will help develop your skills. Develop that random skill of yours. #WealthWednesday

We love all our customers and thought to share a few tips on how to have a fantastic holiday season, avoid the rush and avoid being broke in January #WealthWednesday

Bulk purchasing is key - Stock up on foodstuff and household items that would last you until the end of January. Buy in groups where possible. You‚Äôll be glad you did. Deal with your standing obligations. That 13th month salary you just received could come in handy here. Just clear out the school fees now and see how much shorter the ‚Äòlooooong‚Äô January would be. Plan ahead for trips. It is not too late to start planning. Buy your bus and flight tickets as soon as possible. The closer to Christmas, the more expensive flight and bus tickets become. #WealthWednesday

Take advantage of seasonal sales. You can take advantage of available discounts for necessities with the focus of cutting down costs before Christmas (This should mean extra cash ‚Ä¶Right?) Please don‚Äôt get carried away with all the things on sale. Always ask yourself, do I need this? 

Following these tips may leave you with some extra ‚Äòcash.‚Äô You can use some of these savings to buy gifts for your family and loved ones. Also remember that the best gifts are the most thoughtful not necessarily the most expensive.  #WealthWednesday

Hello everyone, we received some new updates from our pension regulator, about withdrawals from your Voluntary Contributions (VC).  
‚Ä¢ Effective 1 December 2017, only 50% of the VC will be available for withdrawal (subject to tax on income earned) while the 50% balance shall be retained to augment the contributor‚Äôs retirement benefits at retirement.
‚Ä¢ Also, withdrawals from VC can only be made once every 2 years, while subsequent withdrawals shall only be on the additional contributions made after the last withdrawal.
‚Ä¢ For Exempted/Foreign Contributors; withdrawals shall only be once every 2 years. However, total withdrawal of all the funds is allowed subject to tax deduction on both the income earned and principal amount if the withdrawal is done less than 5 years from the date of contribution.
‚Ä¢ In addition, Pension Fund Administrators (PFAs) & Pension Fund Custodians (PFCs) must report any single transaction of N5m and above to the EFCC

If you are a return VC withdrawal applicant & would like to process one, please click the link - http://bit.ly/StanbicPen
If you‚Äôre a first-time applicant, kindly submit your application at any Stanbic IBTC office closest to you.

For more information, call 01 271 6000 or email pensionsolution@stanbicibtc.com

Jude worked full time with an oil and gas firm while Toke, his wife was a full time home manager.
This arrangement gave her time to raise their kids & run a small business from home especially as they did not want a live-in help though they could afford it. When crude oil prices slumped, many oil and gas firms cut down production. Unfortunately, Jude lost his job due to a massive retrenchment. Although he received a decent payout, he couldn‚Äôt secure another job at the time. Jude and Toke however knew that although the payout was huge, they needed to manage the money to ensure that their short terms needs were met, but also in such a way that it would possibly appreciate in value. But they were not really sure what their best options were. Jude‚Äôs friends were suggesting all sorts and he got really confused. Luckily, his wife knew just the right thing to do! (talk about women having the answers, right?!).  They agreed that they needed to preserve their capital while deciding what to do next.

Apparently, Toke‚Äôs uncle had encouraged her to start saving by investing in the Stanbic IBTC Money Market mutual fund a few years ago, she also enabled a direct debit feature on her ‚Äò‚Äôhome management allowance‚Äô‚Äô account which ensured she set aside something monthly.
Toke told Jude about the money in her money market fund.  When she showed him her account and the returns, he was so impressed. #WealthWednesday

She knew we could help so they called to speak to one of our financial advisors who helped them decide on the investment outlets that could match their needs. You too can also start small. Open a money market fund now with as low as #5,000 via https://lnkd.in/e5gQpwK

Art is a movable asset and can be very valuable. Artworks by the ' Masters ' - Van Gogh, Picasso and Rembrandt among a few others - command millions in pounds, dollars.
Here in Nigeria, Ben Enwonwu, Bruce Onobrakpeya, El Anatsui and their likes are the ‚Äòmasters‚Äô and their work fetches tens of millions in Naira as well.
The beauty you see in art can also be used to create financial wealth you know? As an artist becomes better known, his/her artworks appreciate in value.
If you buy art when it‚Äôs cheap and sell when it appreciates, you can make money. You can identify artists before they become commercial successes and collect their pieces. #WealthWednesday #ArtXLagos

Investing in art also helps you diversify from investing in only traditional financial investments. So, you see, your perspective is more valuable than you realise.
Art is also an insurable asset, as it is essential to guard against property theft or title in the event that the title is defective.
As trust assets, they may be used to create an art legacy which you could leave behind for a cause or for your loved ones like the wise man JayZ suggested.

Have you ever been in a situation where you gave a friend money to buy something for you but the money was squandered? How was this situation managed?  #WealthWednesday

If no, you are lucky! But Nnamdi was not so fortunate which is why we want to share his story so we can learn. Nnamdi is currently in the United States and has been there for a while. He earns a decent living #WealthWednesday

This ensured that he was getting regular income in dollars. He was looking to return home so he wanted to build his dream home in Nigeria. There is such a thing as ‚Äò‚Äôtoo much money‚Äô‚Äô but who could he trust to manage these funds? Should it be Chinedu, his spendthrift brother or his uncle? He chose the latter. #WealthWednesday

However, he soon discovered that all the monies he sent home for a building project had been spent by this supposedly trusted uncle. He was really bitter about this situation but decided to keep working hard towards achieving his original goal #WealthWednesday

¬†Luckily, a friend visiting him from Nigeria also encouraged him to start saving again. His friend told him about how he was able to save towards his mortgage equity payment through Mutual Funds managed by Stanbic IBTC¬† https://lnkd.in/e8cC77c
Nnamdi found this interesting and decided to start too, He was excited to know he could save in naira and dollars. #WealthWednesday

You can bet Nnamdi‚Äôs finances are now sorted. The best part is that he no longer has the need to coordinate ‚Äò‚Äôvillage meetings‚Äô‚Äô over the phone on his mismanaged funds. What are you waiting for? You too can start building your own savings today. Send us a DM or reach us via email or a call.¬† Wherever you are, we can #MoveYouForward in #NairaOrDollars #WealthWednesday

Hello people, we have probably heard this saying ‚Äò‚Äôfailing to plan, is planning to fail‚Äô‚Äô, which is why we thought to ask this question today. Let‚Äôs engage, at what age do you think that it is appropriate to start saving towards retirement? Why? Let us know your thoughts. #WealthWednesday  #StanbicIBTCPensions #SIPML #Pension #NigerianPension #PFA #PensionFund #Pension #Retirement #Retire #Retirewell #Education #Learning #FinancialPlanning #Save #Savings

If your answer is No, at what age do you think it is appropriate to start saving towards retirement? There are several reasons to save for retirement. Do you agree that an important reason is to do so for the rainy day? Amongst other reasons, the idea of having a retirement saving is to ensure an income is guaranteed at retirement. #wealthwednesday

At a younger age you are still strong to work hard enough to earn a reasonable income through your salary or business. Don‚Äôt spend it all. The smart thing to do is to set aside some funds towards your retirement. Committing a portion of your income over a period of time (systematic saving and investing) has significant benefits. One of the ways to take advantage of compounding is to start setting aside savings towards retirement now!  #wealthwednesday

Nigeria‚Äôs contributory pension scheme is one of the tax efficient ways of saving as your contributions are deducted before tax is applied on your salary. Tbh there‚Äôs nothing worse than being unable to work because of old age only to realize that you have not saved. Think about it, when you are younger, your whole life is ahead of you and you have something older people would love to reclaim - time. #WealthWednesday
Are you now thinking about saving towards retirement? Make us a partner on your journey to retirement, don‚Äôt spend all you earn today. #WealthWednesday

Ensure you leave a Legacee, by writing a will. Why, you may ask? 
Executors of a will be notified to commence the probate process once death occurs. The probate process involves notifying all institutions where assets are held to forestall imposters from accessing funds.

Can you provide the missing word? ‚ÄúPrevention is better than___‚Äô‚Äô #WealthWednesday

As your financial advisers, your health is just as important to us as your wealth. You need to be alive & well first!
So this #WealthWednesday will focus on preventive care to kickstart the second half of the year. Why it‚Äôs important & what you should do.
Most people rarely go for medical check-ups, they think they don‚Äôt need one since, they are not actually sick yet.

However, a routine preventive exam can identify potential health problems early when they may be easier to treat. 
Don't think ‚Äòif it is not broken, don‚Äôt fix it‚Äô. This works for appliances but is a poor approach for your health. 
This is why doctors say not to wait until you are sick to get physicals done, especially for people 40 years old and older. #WealthWednesday

So, why do you need regular medical check-ups? 
‚û¢ To aid the early detection of ailments and prevention of complications that could be detrimental or cause death. 
‚û¢ To detect if you have high or low blood sugar, hepatitis B & high or low blood pressure etc.

‚û¢ For vision and eye care tests. An optometrist can check for glaucoma & other eye diseases, provide vision reports and possible prescriptions, should you need them.
‚û¢ People between 50 and 65 should have eye checks at least every two years, while those over the age of 65 should have a test every year.
‚û¢ People with some eye issues or with increased risk of these issues should talk to their ophthalmologist.

‚û¢ Women get to have a pap test for cervical cancer, which is deadly and strikes young women. 
‚û¢ Screen for colon cancer - this is a curable but lethal cancer if it is not diagnosed early. Tests are usually reserved for people over 50. 
‚û¢ Mammogram and prostate cancer screening to be sure that you are not at risk of breast or prostate cancer.

Please make a commitment to look after your health. If you take your cars and generators for servicing on due dates, what about your body? 
#WealthWednesday.
As we cross into the second half of the year, find out if your medical insurance provides for a comprehensive check-up and use it. #WealthWednesday.

Retirement is an important milestone and every now and then, we celebrate a retirement, for a parent or a close relative. #WealthWednesday
We know you get worried about how they will fare now that they are retired. Will they get their money? When? All valid concerns. #WealthWednesday

If your parents are due to retire soon, you will want to know what will happen next. Today, we‚Äôll tell you about annuities.
With pensions, an annuity is a guaranteed, regular payment that removes the risk of retirees running out of money #WealthWednesday
With the annuity option, one gets a lump sum payment with the rest of the retirement savings sent to an insurance company #WealthWednesday
An annuity guarantees that the retiree gets a payment from the PFA on a monthly, quarterly, bi annual or annual basis. #WealthWednesday
Stanbic IBTC Insurance Brokers will provide quotes on annuity from different insurance companies so retirees have a choice.  #WealthWednesday
Only approved insurance companies can offer annuity products & the investment of annuity funds is supervised by @PenComNig #WealthWednesday
Our insurance brokers also ensure that the retirees‚Äô beneficiaries get the necessary benefits in the event of death. #WealthWednesday

Here are some of the annuity types we offer‚Ä¶
Level Income ‚Äì This is a fixed payment plan where the retiree collects the same amount of pension from start of the policy to the end.

Here are some of the annuity types we offer‚Ä¶
Spouse Annuity ‚Äì This policy provides cover for your spouse up to 50%, 75% and 100% of your pension. When the retiree dies, the spouse automatically becomes the annuitant and gets the payments for the rest of their life.

Here are some of the annuity types we offer‚Ä¶
Increasing Annuity ‚Äì This plan allows for an increase in the annuity amount at each policy anniversary. The standard increase offered is usually 5% or 7.5% each year on a compounding basis.

Stanbic IBTC can advise you further on the benefits of annuity as a form of pension payment.  Interested? Please call 01 270 2852 or email insurancesolution@stanbicibtc.com

Hey guys! Back to the hustle from the long weekend! Bet you got some much needed sleep. On average, how long do you sleep? 
For today‚Äôs #WealthWednesday we will be talking about the importance of sleep. I mean, sleep is essential to your health.

Sleep is a basic necessity of life. It is as important as air, food and water. It determines if we wake up feeling refreshed, alert and ready for the day. 
Sleep is important because it also determines if our jobs, relationships, productivity, health and safety will suffer. 
So let‚Äôs do a little Sleep Diagnosis. How do you sleep? #WealthWednesday
If you said yes to one or more of the above listed symptoms, you just may be sleep deficient. Sleep deprivation does have long term negative effects. #WealthWednesday
Although sleep experts generally recommend an average of 7-9 hours per night, some people can get along with less while others need as much as 10 hours to feel alert the next day. #WealthWednesday

Let‚Äôs look up a few sleep myths. 

1. You can "cheat" on the amount of sleep you get.
Sleep experts say most adults need between 7-9 hours of sleep each night for optimum performance, health and safety. 
When we don't get adequate sleep, we accumulate a sleep debt that can be difficult to "pay back" if it becomes too big. 

2. Snoring is a common problem, especially among men, but it isn‚Äôt harmful. #WealthWednesday
3. Turning up the radio, opening the window, or turning on the AC are effective ways to stay awake when driving. #WealthWednesday
4. Insomnia is characterized by difficulty falling asleep. #WealthWEdnesday
5. Daytime sleepiness always means a person isn't getting enough sleep.
6. Health problems such as obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and depression are unrelated to the amount and quality of a person's sleep.
7. The older you get, the fewer hours of sleep you need. Another misconception. #WealthWednesday

Why do we need to pay attention to getting good sleep? #WealthWednesday

We know a lot of you have concerns about whether you will eventually be able to access your Retirement Benefits #wealthwednesday

The great news is, you do not even have to wait until retirement to access your pension benefits 
There are also certain conditions under which your retirement savings will be made available to you prior to retirement. 
Have no fear, this edition of #wealthwednesday is focused on enlightening you on the various conditions for accessing ones retirement benefits.

There are actually 5 of such conditions and we will discuss them briefly in the succeeding posts. Stay with us.
At Retirement ‚Ä¶well, this is a given right? Retirement is valid from age 50 and above or based on the terms of your employment. 
-  Your total balance can be paid enbloc if you have less than 550,000. 
-  If balance in RSA account is more than 550,000, you will be paid an initial lump sum whilst the balance will be paid out. 
-  Periodically on either a  programmed withdrawal basis 
OR you choose to buy an annuity  with the balance (monthly or quarterly). 
-  We can advise you on both options. 
#wealthwednesday

'- If you‚Äôre not yet 50 years old have been out of job for 4 months, you can access 25% of your pension balance. 
- The balance will be due to the RSA holder at age 50 or when (s)he retires, whichever is later.
- Withdrawals  can also be based on medical grounds irrespective of age based on advice from a certified physician or medical board. 
- If the RSA holder has been reported missing for more than a year, the beneficiary or NOK can also access the pension savings.
- If the RSA holder dies, the beneficiary or NOK can also access the retirement savings with  a valid will or LOA 
#wealthwednesday

Each of these conditions will require relevant documentation and approval  from @PenCom though, we are super careful with your money ‚ò∫Ô∏è 
#wealthwednesday

Good morning, Nigeria. We want to share some really topical information with you this #WealthWednesday. 
We are primarily concerned about your financial health but your physical & mental fitness is also important to us. 
After all, good health really is wealth!

As end to end financial advisers, we have seen 1st-hand the stretchy impact of these challenging times on people. 
Things are really tough and people are very stressed. We owe it to ourselves to stay mentally healthy. #WealthWednesday

Today, we will be talking about depression. We begin with 4 things you should know about depression. #WealthWednesday
‚Ä¢ Depression is a real illness
‚Ä¢ Depression affects people in different ways
‚Ä¢ Depression is treatable
‚Ä¢ If you have depression, you are not alone

They are likely to be very irritable, lose interest in once-pleasurable activities, and have difficulty sleeping. They may act recklessly.
Some people turn to alcohol or drugs when they are depressed. They also may become frustrated, discouraged, irritable, angry and abusive.
Some may throw themselves into their work to avoid talking about their depression with family or friends.
Sometimes it can be difficult to distinguish grief from major depression. However, grief that is complicated and lasts for a very long time following a loss may require treatment.
Older adults who had depression when they were younger are more at risk for developing depression in later life. #WealthWednesday

Many of us think depression is simply sadness. It isn‚Äôt. Sadness is a normal reaction to difficult events and periods and we usually get over it. 
Sadness is only a small part of depression. Some people with depression may not feel sadness at all. Depression has many other symptoms, including physical ones. #WealthWednesday

When a person has depression, it interferes with daily life & normal functioning. It can cause pain for the person with depression and those who care about them.  #WealthWednesday
Depression is not a sign of a person‚Äôs weakness or a character flaw. It is important to not diminish people for being depressed. 
You can‚Äôt just ‚Äúsnap out of‚Äù clinical depression and most people who experience depression need treatment to get better. 
If you have been experiencing any of the following signs and symptoms for at least 2 weeks, you may be suffering from depression:

There are many factors that play a role in depression. A few of them are: Genetics, brain biology and chemistry, and life events such as trauma, loss of a loved one, a difficult relationship, an early childhood experience, or any stressful situation.
Depression can happen at any age, but often begins in the teens or early 20s or 30s.
The severity and frequency of symptoms, and how long they last, will vary depending on the individual.
Even children can get depression. The child may pretend to be sick, refuse to go to school, cling to a parent, or worry that a parent may die. #WealthWednesday

Older children and teens with depression may sulk, get into trouble at school, be negative and irritable, and feel misunderstood. If you‚Äôre unsure if an adolescent in your life is depressed or just ‚Äúbeing a teenager,‚Äù consider how long the symptoms have been present, how severe they are, and how different the teen is acting from his or her usual self.
Teens with depression may also have other disorders such as anxiety, eating disorders, or substance abuse. They may also be at higher risk for suicide.
Adults with depression do not all experience the same symptoms. Typical symptoms include sadness, worthlessness, and guilt. #WealthWednesday

Depression, even the most severe cases, can be treated. The earlier treatment begins, the more effective it is.
Most adults see an improvement in their symptoms when treated with antidepressant drugs, talk therapy (psychotherapy), or a combination of both.
As the pressure of life mounts, we must be more watchful for those we love. Please notice the signs and symptoms and show some more understanding. If you think you may have depression, start by making an appointment to see your doctor or health care provider. 
#WealthWednesday
Just talk to someone. Many more people than you think will care.
There are many different types of depression. Symptoms can range from relatively minor through to very severe, so its helpful to be aware of the range of conditions and symptoms. #WealthWednesday
Here are more types of depression. #WealthWednesday"

It‚Äôs that time of the week again and this time we will be discussing something that we rarely talk about‚Ä¶Estate Planning. Estate planning involves sorting out the disposal of your assets while you‚Äôre still alive and well. For the benefit of those you love #WealthWednesday
Having an estate plan is an essential part of preserving your assets. The basics of protecting your assets for your family through estate planning involves Wills and Trusts #WealthWednesday

‚ÄúHol‚Äôup, hol‚Äôup!‚Äù Yes, we know wills are a touchy subject but look at it this way: life is beautiful and unfair. Passing on has nothing to do with how old or healthy you are. Unfortunately, even children die right after they are born. Also, a Will is really just a document that lists the assets you have, who should get them and how they should get them when you pass on. #WealthWednesday

You may be thinking: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have assets, jare‚Äù Do you know the cash in your wallet right now is an asset? You probably also have money in your bank account and a Retirement Savings Account. What about those designer items? #WealthWednesday

Your beneficiaries only get assured access to your assets if you have an executed Will or a Letter of Administration. Getting a letter of administration can be harrowing and expensive for the recently bereaved. #WealthWednesday

And even then, your assets could still be distributed using Customary Law, sometimes to the detriment of those closest to you. This all sounds a bit depressing and it really is. Imagine others gaining the benefit of your life‚Äôs work while your loved ones struggle. It‚Äôs time to put your wishes down in a Will to avoid family disputes and ensure your loved ones are well taken care of. You know us. We‚Äôre discreet and quietly efficient at this. It‚Äôs our work. Email us SITLAgency@stanbicibtc.com with any questions! #WealthWednesday
A Trust lets you to set aside some assets for a particular objective by passing the rights to the assets to a trustee. #WealthWednesday

A quick explanation of the terms. With a Living Trust, you get a first-hand experience of how your wishes would be adhered to when you pass on. A Corporate Trust is a going concern and does not die, you are rest assured that the objective of the Trust would be adhered to. Assets transferred into a Living Trust go to your beneficiaries in line with your wishes avoiding the delay and expenses of the Probate process. #WealthWednesday

And because Trust assets do not go through Probate, the Trust is not subject to estate tax, when you pass on. You‚Äôre also assured of confidentiality under a Trust unlike a Will which is a public document that can be viewed in a court . #WealthWednesday

What‚Äôs the best thing about a trust? The assets are continually invested by our Investment Managers, so the assets grow to keep providing value. Make a smart decision today by preserving your assets for your loved ones #WealthWednesday #EstatePlan #PreservingAssets

Meet Ada ‚Äì She got her first job in January...first salary this week! HR just called to ask for her RSA details. #WealthWednesday

What is RSA? 
RSA = Retirement Savings Account. It is the easiest way to ensure savings are targeted directly for retirement. #WealthWednesday

Ada asks Olu who just joined the company too: ‚ÄúHow does this RSA thing work? Do you know?‚Äù An RSA is an account funded by a percentage of your monthly salary. 18% of your salary to be specific. These contributions come from both you (8%) and your employer (10%) so 18% of your *total monthly pay. #WealthWednesday

You can decide to make your own extra contributions to your RSA. These are called voluntary contributions. This account, your RSA is managed for you by a Pension Fund Administrator (PFA). Hopefully usÔÅä. If it‚Äôs not us, WYD? #WealthWednesday

Your PFA gives you a personal identification number (PIN) for your RSA. This is your ‚Äúaccount number‚Äù aka RSA PIN. With your RSA PIN, you can check your account balance to know how much you‚Äôve saved for the future. #WealthWednesday

The PFA invests the money in your RSA to earn returns for you. Unlike bank accounts, you can have only one RSA. When the transfer window opens, you can move to us though. Yes, a transfer window closed last night, but we‚Äôre not talking football #WealthWednesday

Companies with more than 3 employees must make pension contributions to their staff‚Äôs RSAs. Nigerian law says so. When you retire, you can get the money in your RSA pretty easily. We have paid over N200bn to our retirees so far #WealthWednesday

1.4m professionals like you trust us with their RSAs and their hopes and dreams for retirement. Partly because we‚Äôre easily reachable through many channels. On the phone, via webchat, on social media & in person #WealthWednesday
Ask us anything else you want to know about pensions. We are here to make sure you retire well ÔÅä #WealthWednesday

"How have you been doing with your budgeting this year? Here are a few tips to help keep your budget on track.
1. Hide your money from yourself: Get multiple bank accounts and one without a debit card. That way you can tuck away money for holidays or car repairs that you can't access. That will protect your funds from impulse purchases.
2. Start saving for Christmas now: Put away a bit each month, that way you have cash on hand to buy presents and not have to rely on credit.
3. Think small: Don't budget for a full year; it might be daunting. Start by budgeting for each month."
